Name: Warner Bros Discovery
Name_1: ‚ÄòDune‚Äô Is Opening in Movie Theaters‚Ä¶ and Your Living Room. Here‚Äôs Why That‚Äôs a Mistake (Column)
Text_1:
‚ÄúDune‚Äù has the potential to be the biggest movie of the year. But however well it does or does not do at the box office it‚Äôs undeniably the biggest grandest slice of movie in a long time. Big as in vast. As in images and sounds that fill the screen and fill the senses. Big as in: The movie transports you to the desert planet of Arrakis and for 2 hours and 35 minutes you live there.

So why would this overwhelmingly epic visually spectacular one-of-a-kind sci-fi popcorn movie be opening Oct. 22 on a television set near you?

We know the answer and there‚Äôs a kind of petty spreadsheet logic to it. ‚ÄúDune‚Äù is opening simultaneously in movie theaters and on home screens because Warner Bros. the company that Wikipedia now describes as ‚Äúan American diversified multinational mass media and entertainment conglomerate‚Äù also owns HBO Max the streaming service where ‚ÄúDune‚Äù will be made available (for no extra cost) to subscribers. Warner Bros. is owned by AT&T and will be merging probably next year with Discovery. The revamped company will have many interlocking priorities. In the first year of the pandemic which was the year of HBO Max‚Äôs ostensibly game-changing launch it became a transcendent corporate goal for Warner Bros. to do all it could to put its new streaming service into orbit. And since people for most of last year couldn‚Äôt go to the movies it was decided that each of the studio‚Äôs 2021 films would be made available the same day it‚Äôs released in theaters on HBO Max.

The pandemic is still with us of course. But the year when people couldn‚Äôt go to the movies is over. Moviegoing has returned in force. And at a moment when many have begun to question the wisdom of opening a film simultaneously in theaters and at home (day-and-date as it‚Äôs known) ‚ÄúDune‚Äù now stands as the apotheosis of an issue hovering over the entertainment industry and defining it. The question is: Does it really make sense to take one of the most feverishly anticipated movie extravaganzas of the decade and give it away to folks in their living rooms?

Popular on Variety

I think there are two basic potential scenarios for how the release of ‚ÄúDune‚Äù could play out. One is that on opening weekend the film crashes and burns making back just a small fraction of the $165 million it cost to produce (which of course doesn‚Äôt include the huge sum it cost to market). The whole world pronounces it a disappointment and a bomb. If that happens the HBO Max release will be seen to have been a disaster ‚Äî but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a very likely scenario. There‚Äôs simply too much anticipation for ‚ÄúDune‚Äù on the part of three generations of sci-fi fans who are devotees of Frank Herbert‚Äôs 1965 novel (not to mention its daisy chain of sequels).

Far likelier is the following scenario: that on opening weekend ‚ÄúDune‚Äù does‚Ä¶ okay. The highest opening-weekend gross earned by a movie so far this year is the $94 million made by ‚ÄúShang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings‚Äù over the long Labor Day weekend followed by the $80 million made by ‚ÄúBlack Widow‚Äù and the $70 million made by ‚ÄúF9: The Fast Saga.‚Äù (Sorry but when did ‚ÄúThe Fast Saga‚Äù becomes part of that movie‚Äôs title? They should really lose that.) Of course ‚ÄúShang-Chi‚Äù opened exclusively in theaters. But let‚Äôs say that ‚ÄúDune‚Äù manages to post receipts in that range. If so a qualified victory will be declared and we‚Äôll be left speculating about how much the movie might have made if it weren‚Äôt competing with itself on TV. We‚Äôll also speculate about what it would have made on opening weekend in pre-pandemic times. So if it makes say $50 million three weekends from now how much of that shortfall will be pandemic-related and how much will be HBO Max-related?

Warner Bros. will take all that speculation ‚Äî the lack of certainty ‚Äî and use it as cover for its decision. The studio would say in essence ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre fine with a $50 million opening. Under different circumstances who can say how well the movie would have performed?‚Äù And of course they‚Äôll double down on making the argument for how much it helps the company‚Äôs bottom line to offer the film on HBO Max. A movie like ‚ÄúDune‚Äù is a subscription magnet; that‚Äôs the whole point. And for entertainment conglomerates imitating the model invented by Netflix subscriptions have become the coin of the realm. Winning massive numbers of subscribers is the new ‚ÄúIt opened huge!‚Äù

Or so goes the reasoning. But it‚Äôs amazing how much common sense ‚Äúsophisticated‚Äù business rationales can leave behind. It‚Äôs now too late for Warner Bros. to reverse its day-and-date decision about ‚ÄúDune‚Äù ‚Äî commitments have been made logistics have been locked in ‚Äî but here are a few reasons why I think it will prove to be a mistake.

1. The film will be less profitable. If ‚ÄúDune‚Äù opens with $50 million it will be clear that the studio left a lot of money on the table. Especially if the grosses seriously decline in the weeks ahead. The movie has already opened in international markets (exclusively in theaters) where it is doing well but using its domestic take as a yardstick let‚Äôs say it winds up matching ‚ÄúShang-Chi‚Äôs‚Äù total receipts which are closing in on $200 million. That sounds like a lot of money but this is ‚ÄúDune‚Äù we‚Äôre talking about. It‚Äôs being marketed as the new ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù meets ‚ÄúLord of the Rings.‚Äù It should be far and away the biggest movie of the year.

2. Making ‚ÄúDune‚Äù a day-and-date release radically cuts down on the film‚Äôs event status. It does so in two ways. If ‚ÄúDune‚Äù were available in theaters only the revenues would probably spike ‚Äî but those numbers would also become a billboard a way of saying ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the movie you have to see.‚Äù More important is that you‚Äôd feel you have to go to the theater to see it because it belongs in a theater. The bigness of movies is primal. It‚Äôs been a key aspect of cinema for 100 years going back to silent films like ‚ÄúIntolerance‚Äù stretching into the widescreen sagas of the ‚Äô50s and ‚Äô60s (‚ÄúLawrence of Arabia‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Greatest Story Ever Told‚Äù ‚Äú2001: A Space Odyssey‚Äù) into the Lucas/ Spielberg ‚Äô70s (‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù ‚ÄúClose Encounters of the Third Kind‚Äù) and beyond. In an age when even the ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù universe has been successfully shrunk down to TV size I would argue that the gargantuan quality of ‚ÄúDune‚Äù is almost its key selling point. The film is something to gawk at like ‚ÄúLawrence of Arabia‚Äù with Mayan design and insect helicopters. It‚Äôs something you don‚Äôt see every day or every year. But the awesome singularity of ‚ÄúDune‚Äù is compromised when you tell your audience ‚ÄúOkay the bigness isn‚Äôt essential. It‚Äôs fine to watch it at home.‚Äù

3. It‚Äôs going to play a lot less well on television. Growing up I once watched ‚Äú2001: A Space Odyssey‚Äù on a 16-inch black-and-white TV set and it actually worked. That‚Äôs how great a movie it is. ‚ÄúDune‚Äù is a lot less great. I would argue that it‚Äôs a reasonably commanding sci-fi parable that begins to run out of gas in its last hour. That‚Äôs because Frank Herbert in the ‚ÄúDune‚Äù books may have been a better world-builder than he was a storyteller. (I would say that‚Äôs true of J.R.R. Tolkien too but we can debate that another time.) The world of ‚ÄúDune‚Äù like the world of ‚ÄúLawrence of Arabia‚Äù or the original ‚ÄúBlade Runner‚Äù needs to overwhelm and envelop you. But if you watch it at home the film‚Äôs narrative ‚Äî is Paul Atreides the Messiah? Watch the House Atreides go down to defeat‚Ä¶ and look out for that sandworm! ‚Äî is going to stand revealed as the rather patchy affair it is. When you shrink the grandeur of ‚ÄúDune‚Äù you shrink its appeal.

4. The entire industry has a vested interest in the success of ‚ÄúDune.‚Äù It used to be that if a major movie turned out to be a commercial disappointment the only people who suffered were those connected to it including the executives at that studio. (In the rest of the industry there was schadenfreude.) But thanks to the karmic double whammy of the streaming revolution and the pandemic the whole world is suddenly asking if movies in theaters have a future. I think they do but it‚Äôs not foregone. And part of it is that we need to see the enthusiasm of movie-theater audiences to be reminded of what a potent force they are. Last summer ‚ÄúTenet‚Äù was supposed to be the movie that jump-started moviegoing; for various reasons (notably the stubbornness of the pandemic) that didn‚Äôt work out so well. But movies in the last six months have indeed been jump-started and that makes ‚ÄúDune‚Äù the right movie at the right time. It‚Äôs a film that could remind us of the primacy ‚Äî and profitability ‚Äî of the theater experience. You wouldn‚Äôt want every movie to be like ‚ÄúDune.‚Äù But you want ‚ÄúDune‚Äù to be ‚ÄúDune.‚Äù If it turns into the commercially compromised lagging version of itself that becomes a gigantic blown opportunity. And everyone suffers.

Of course there‚Äôs another possibility in all this. ‚ÄúDune‚Äù opens on Oct. 22 people watch it on HBO Max and it still goes on to be a massive theatrical hit. It breaks the bank. That would be a happy ending one that might help rewrite the rules of what‚Äôs coming. But I‚Äôm not holding my breath.
Name_2: WarnerMedia consolidates six Asia offices with Singapore hub | Media
Text_2:
Building on the restructuring of its Asia business announced in November 2020 and the appointment of Clement Schwebig to lead this recast business WarnerMedia has opened a hub in Singapore. This new facility which employs 300 people--with more people being hired currently--integrates six offices in the region (four in Singapore and two in Hong Kong) and consolidates the presence of multiple businesses including Warner Bros HBO and Turner.

In addition WarnerMedia expects to substantially increase additional roles in Singapore in the coming years including those in the technology field as the company increases focus on its direct-to-consumer streaming business led by Amit Malhotra managing director for HBO Max in Southeast Asia India and Korea. The streaming service's Asia headquarters will be at this hub.

Clement Schwebig and Amit Malhotra

WarnerMedia did not indicate if there were any job redundancies as a result of this consolidation in APAC and the opening of this 40000 square foot facility across two floors at Solaris in Fusionopolis the city state‚Äôs media and tech business park.

‚ÄúAs we get ready to launch HBO Max in our first Asian markets we‚Äôll build on WarnerMedia‚Äôs legacy of incredible stories and introduce a brand-new streaming experience for our fans in the region‚Äù Malhotra said. ‚ÄúOur new office space in Singapore as a regional HQ will be the perfect backdrop for the innovative work to be done in the lead up to our launch.‚Äù

‚ÄúHere in Singapore we have long supported a sizeable ecosystem for the entertainment broadcast production and licensing industries" added Schwebig. "From our new Singapore hub we will continue with our ambitious plans for the region.‚Äù

The hub was opened on September 24 2021 by Singapore‚Äôs minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo and was joined by Lew Chuen Hong chief executive of the Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore.
Name_3: 'Army of Thieves' Trailer Shows Off Prequel To Zack Snyder's 'Army of the Dead'
Text_3:
‚ÄòArmy of Thieves‚Äô Trailer Shows Off Prequel To Zack Snyder‚Äôs ‚ÄòArmy of the Dead‚Äô

During Saturday‚Äôs TUDUM online fan event Netflix released the Army of Thieves trailer which is a prequel movie to Zack Snyder‚Äôs recent Army of the Dead zombie heist flick. ‚ÄúIn this prequel to Zack Snyder‚Äôs Army of the Dead small-town bank teller Dieter gets drawn into the adventure of a lifetime when a mysterious woman [‚Ä¶]
Name_4: Keeler: Broncos fans take a bow. You made Empower Field feel like Empower Field again. Loud. Proud.
Text_4:
Man he missed the pizza. The pizza and the smack.

John Ayala and his family parked the family‚Äôs gorgeous three-wheel trike in lot E4 at Empower Field a few hours before the Broncos‚Äô home opener on Sunday as if the pandemic never happened.

About 20 yards away a large tailgate of about 50 or so New York Jets fans had gathered hoping for the best but with a rookie quarterback on the road knowing better.

Every few minutes the gang in green launched into their beloved cheer in unison:

‚ÄúJ-E-T ‚Ä¶

And every time before those 50 got to the ‚ÄúS‚Äù in ‚ÄúJets‚Äù John or his brother or a cousin would walk over to the trike and pull a lever that set off the mother of all horns.

‚ÄúThis is beautiful‚Äù Ayala said of Sunday‚Äôs home opener. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs being able to share a camaraderie with others who are the same as you ‚Äî blue and orange.‚Äù

‚ÄúJ-E-T ‚Ä¶‚Äù

Honnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnk!

‚ÄúYou listen to music get a beer and a shot have a good time‚Äù John continued. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs beautiful man.‚Äù

Especially because like most Broncos fans Ayala couldn‚Äôt do this last year. And for a guy who grew up partying in the south stands it hurt like Hades.

His wife works for the Department of Public Health. With a newborn due in August 2021 John got every vaccine shot he could. And when Ayala put down a deposit on his Broncos season tickets for 2020 realizing that the odds of actually getting into the building were slim he took the option to push those seats into 2021.

‚ÄúI was looking at some of the (first two) games we played away and I was amazed by how many Broncos fans (there were) ‚Äî the orange was just unbelievable‚Äù Ayala said. ‚ÄúSo Broncos Country is hard core. And having Teddy Bridgewater and maybe (general manager) George Paton that‚Äôs gonna be the new chapter in these games.‚Äù

The weather was perfect even if the traffic flow wasn‚Äôt. Shutout? Check. 3-0 start? Check. First place? Check. Postseason momentum? Check. The first Broncos game at full capacity since December 2019 managed to squeeze in a little bit of everything live music included.

A few lots down from John and his family Sergio Gomez a native of Barnum West danced and swayed behind a giant grill in C11 while local band El Pollo Y Su Pandilla ‚Äî The Chicken And His Gang ‚Äî played with gusto just over his left shoulder.

‚ÄúThis is Denver Colorado right here‚Äù Garcia shouted over the music.

‚ÄúThis is what Denver is all about. It‚Äôs about the Broncos. It doesn‚Äôt matter who you are or where you‚Äôre from. We can all unite for the same thing: The Denver Broncos.‚Äù

Scale of 1-10 how much did you miss this last fall?

‚ÄúOh an 11‚Äù Gomez shouted this time with a grin. ‚ÄúAn 11.

‚ÄúGoing in that stadium win or lose you‚Äôre there supporting the team supporting the city supporting the state. It‚Äôs about diversity. Everyone comes together when it comes to the Denver Broncos.‚Äù

And when it comes to giving grief to visiting fans.

‚ÄúJ-E-T ‚Ä¶‚Äù

Honnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnk!

That‚Äôll show ‚Äôem.

‚ÄúThere are only eight of these in Colorado‚Äù Ayala said of The Bronco which features a 454 big-block Chevy engine and Broncos-themed airbrushing from front wheel to back bumper. ‚ÄúThe frame is from New Mexico. Everything else is custom.‚Äù

All the way to the storage box in the back a cabinet lovingly adorned with a painting of Empower Field and the numbers from the Broncos‚Äô Ring of Fame.

‚ÄúI think (normalcy) is going to take a little bit because people aren‚Äôt so sure that this is the real deal‚Äù Ayala reflected. ‚ÄúThe past five years we‚Äôve had some bad decisions and quarterbacks.‚Äù

With that someone handed him a plate with two steaming pizza slices on top. Old habits in E4 they die hard.

So do old friendships.

‚ÄúThis is my boy right here‚Äù John laughed. ‚ÄúThey make their own pizza. You just meet people from all over the place here. You get to know each other. It‚Äôs like a family. It‚Äôs a community. It‚Äôs beautiful.‚Äù

The cutline on the top photo in this story has been updated.
Name_5: Draco Malfoy Is Only On Camera In Harry Potter For 31 Minutes
Text_5:
Wait surely the headline can't be true can it?

Almost 20 years after the Harry Potter franchise made its big-screen debut several Potterheads on social media have stumbled upon a shocking discovery - that Draco Malfoy Harry's arch-nemesis and a major antagonist throughout the series appears on screen throughout the whole saga for as little as 31 minutes.

31 minutes?! Are you serious? That's barely longer than an episode of Friends!

Advert

Instagram/t22felton

Apparently though it's true and a quick glance at the official Harry Potter IMDB page confirms that Felton's character does indeed have just over half an hour of screen-time throughout all 19 hours and 40 minutes of the eight films - around 2.5 percent of the entire run to be specific.

Where does the time go?

To break it down even further Malfoy's longest appearance is in The Half Blood Prince during which the silver-haired bully enjoys a grand total of eight minutes of screen-time.

Advert

In contrast his shortest spell can be found in the fifth instalment of the franchise The Order Of The Phoenix in which he manages to appear on-screen for just one minute and 15 seconds.

Warner Bros

Understandably fans were pretty peeved at the revelation.

One Twitter user said: "The fact Draco Malfoy was only in 31 minutes throughout the WHOLE of the Harry Potter franchise (19 hrs & 40 mins) jus doesn't sit right with me."

Advert

Another wrote: "Are you telling me that 14 years old me celebrated the birthday of a character that had 31 minutes on screen?"

However before you start moaning about Felton's apparent shafting by the film's editing crew let's back up for a moment and clear things up. You see screen time in a film is literally - the time an actor is visibly on the screen.



This means that even if Malfoy was in the same room as other characters if the shot was not showing him it wouldn't count as screen time.

Advert

Likewise if he was interacting with someone and the camera switches between characters while they're talking to each other Malfoy's screen time is only counted when it's on him.

In actuality the 31 minutes (and 30 seconds) that Malfoy appears in the films is comparable to several other characters you might consider as prominent. Voldemort for example was on screen for 37 minutes and 15 seconds while Hagrid appeared for 45 minutes and 45 seconds.

Meanwhile Malfoy himself managed to bag more camera time than other long-running Potter mainstays such as Ginny Weasley Neville Longbottom and Professor McGonagall so maybe it's worth taking a step back and putting these things in perspective.



Advert

Still at the end of the day this whole episode just goes to show that screen time isn't everything.

Anthony Hopkins famously only needed 25 minutes of it to win an Oscar for his portrayal of Hannibal Lector in Silence Of The Lambs after all. And judging from the number of passionate fans Felton still has after all these years it's safe to say that his somewhat minimal screentime in Harry Potter certainly didn't diminish his success.

Featured Image Credit: Warner Bros

Topics: Harry Potter Entertainment Film and TV

Name: Waste Management
Name_1: Waste Management Florida: Brevard commercial properties fight illegal trash
Text_1:
Ralph Perrone Sr. has started doing a little bit of sleuthing and what amounts to dumpster-diving to discover who has been putting their trash into the large bins outside his commercial properties.

It might be a receipt with someone's name on it a cardboard box that has a packing label with a mailing address some construction material that matches a project being done at a nearby property.

It does more than just fill up his dumpsters. It's illegal and it's costing Perrone money.

So he has enlisted the help of the Brevard County Sheriff's Office and the State Attorney's Office to help crack down on illegal dumping ‚Äî including making law enforcement more aware of the issue and the illegality of putting trash in someone else's commercial dumpster. State Attorney Phil Archer said he will prosecute such cases.

Perrone said when he tracks down the alleged offenders and follows up with a visit or call most had no idea what they were doing was illegal.

But it is. Illegal dumping can subject violators to third-degree felony charges ‚Äî if they are caught.

Regardless of that Waste Management Inc. charges commercial property owners a surcharge that it calls an "overage fee" if their dumpsters are overflowing meaning trash is over the rim of the dumpster or if trash is piled up next to the dumpster.

And Perrone says he has been nailed to the tune of $100 to $200 a month for the overflowing dumpsters that are the result of other people's trash deposited at his properties on Merritt Island and in Cape Canaveral Cocoa and Rockledge.

More like this:Commissioners vote 3-2 for new trash contract with Waste Management 39% rate increase

Related coverage:COVID-related driver shortage hits Waste Management impacts collection

"When a business dumps their litter in your dumpster in order to save money and avoid paying the proper disposal of that litter they are committing a third-degree felony" Archer said in a letter to Perrone. "It does not matter how much litter as any amount for a commercial purpose is a felony."

Perrone said he has no problem with the rules ‚Äî but he does have a problem with people illegally dumping their trash.

"We are all having a big issue with illegal dumping in our front-loader dumpsters ‚Äî for which we are responsible for" Perrone said. "Contractors lawns services tree services area residential neighbors area commercial business that do not have dumpster service or have too small of a dumpster continue to illegally place their trash and debris into other business and property owners' front-loader dumpsters."

He said anything sticking out over the rim or if the lid won't close can result in a fee to the property owner.

"Waste Management drivers snap photos and you get an extra charge on your next invoice" he said.

Perrone said on one recent occasion he found queen palm logs inside one of his dumpsters. On another occasion he found concrete. In both instances Waste Management would not empty the dumpsters until the material was removed and Perrone was changed an extra fee to have the waste truck return for an unscheduled pickup he said.

At another location Perrone and his staff caught employees of a nearby business dumping trash into a Perrone Properties-owned dumpster.

"The employee stated 'the dumpster their landlord had provided is always full so we use your dumpster. We didn't think you would mind' " Perrone recalled.

Perrone did mind. He decided to call the Brevard County Sheriff's Office for assistance. Perrone said the manager of the nearby business got a visit from two sheriff's deputies who explained the illegality of what the business was doing.

Perrone has attached yellow signs with red lettering to the dumpsters on his commercial properties warning people that putting trash in the dumpsters is illegal if they are not a tenant of the commercial complex. He also is installing surveillance camera pointed at the dumpsters to catch violators.

Just this past week security footage captured someone putting an old mattress in one of Perrone's dumpsters.

And at another location that has a locked dumpster someone dumped old chairs and other refuse adjacent to the dumpster.

Keeping it 'CLEAN' in Brevard

Amy Boyson community affairs manager for Waste Management Inc. of Florida said it is nothing new that her company enforces its rules about overflowing commercial dumpsters.

"Customers have to take some responsibility for their container" Boyson said. "It's just a way to keep our community clean" with trash not blowing around the neighborhood or unsightly mounds of trash bags overflowing from the dumpsters.

Boyson said a Waste Management program it calls CLEAN (an acronym for community litter environmental-protection awareness notice) addresses this issue. The program is in effect locally in unincorporated Brevard as well as Cocoa Beach Indian Harbour Brach Melbourne Satellite Beach and West Melbourne as part of Waste Management contracts with those jurisdictions. The program also is being added in Cocoa and Indialantic she said.

The contract language that allows for an overage charge varies slightly in each community. The language on the contract in unincorporated Brevard County for example has parameters of trash being "12 inches or more over the top of the container" or "solid waste placed on the ground" as triggering the overage charge.

Boyson said Waste Management drivers use a onboard computer to take a digital photo of the waste material that is either overflowing or on the ground.

In a letter that goes out to Waste Management commercial customers found in violation the company says: "Overfilled containers are unsightly and create an environment attractive to unwelcome critters. The mess in your waste area may give the wrong impression of your business to your customers."

Boyson said customers have several options if their bins are overflowing including getting a larger dumpster; adding recycling containers; scheduling more pickups per week; or having a special "lock bar" installed on the dumpster that provides access only to tenants and the trash hauler.

"The goal of a charge is to get the customers' attention to 'right-size' their service to meet their needs" Boyson said.

Archer said he wants to get the word out to the public that his office will prosecute in cases of illegal dumping into trash receptacles ‚Äî as it has in seven felony cases and seven misdemeanor cases locally since 2017.

In cases of non-commercial dumping there are various provisions in state law. Depending on the volume of trash involved it can be a third-degree felony a first-degree misdemeanor or a noncriminal infraction with a civil penalty Archer said.

But in cases of commercial dumping it always is a third-degree felony.

Archer said his office will work with local law enforcement officials who have questions about the details of the littering statute or the sufficiency of a particular investigation.

But Archer added that he would prefer the offenders know that their actions were illegal and they wouldn't do it in the first place.

Dave Berman is business editor at FLORIDA TODAY. Contact Berman at dberman@floridatoday.com. Twitter: @bydaveberman.

If stories like this are important to you please consider subscribing to FLORIDA TODAY. To subscribe: https://cm.floridatoday.com/specialoffer/
Name_2: An alarm went off on SpaceX's all-tourist space flight. The problem was the toilet
Text_2:
New York CNN Business ‚Äî

As Jared Isaacman and his three fellow crewmates were freeflying through Earth‚Äôs orbit shielded from the unforgiving vacuum of space by nothing but a 13-foot-wide carbon-fiber capsule an alarm started blaring.

The SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft‚Äôs systems were warning the crew of a ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù issue Isaacman said. They‚Äôd spent months poring over SpaceX manuals and training to respond to in-space emergencies so they leaped into action working with SpaceX ground controllers to pinpoint the cause of the error.

As it turned out the Crew Dragon wasn‚Äôt in jeopardy. But the on board toilet was.

Nothing in space is easy including going to the bathroom. In a healthy human on Earth making sure everything ends up in the toilet is usually a matter of simple aim. But in space there is no feeling of gravity. There‚Äôs no guarantee that what comes out will go where it‚Äôs supposed to. Waste can ‚Äî and does ‚Äî go in every possible direction.

To solve that problem space toilets have fans inside them which are used to create suction. Essentially they pull waste out of the human body and keep it stored away.

And the Crew Dragon‚Äôs ‚Äúwaste management system‚Äù fans were experiencing mechanical problems. That is what tripped the alarm the crew heard.

Scott ‚ÄúKidd‚Äù Poteet an Inspiration4 mission director who helped oversee the mission from the ground tipped reporters off about the issue in an interview with CBS. Poteet and SpaceX‚Äôs director of crew mission management later confirmed there were ‚Äúissues‚Äù with the waste management system at a press conference but didn‚Äôt go into detail setting off an immediate wave of speculation that the error could‚Äôve created a disastrous mess.

When asked directly about that on Thursday however Isaacman said ‚ÄúI want to be 100% clear: There were no issues in the cabin at all as it relates to that.‚Äù

But Isaacman and his fellow travelers on the Inspiration4 mission did have to work with SpaceX to respond to the problem during their three-day stay in orbit during which they experienced numerous communications blackouts highlighting the importance of the crew‚Äôs thorough training regimen.

‚ÄúI would say probably somewhere around 10% of our time on orbit we had no [communication with the ground] and we were a very calm cool crew during that‚Äù he said adding that ‚Äúmental toughness and a good frame of mind and a good attitude‚Äù were crucial to the mission.

‚ÄúThe psychological aspect is one area where you can‚Äôt compromise because‚Ä¶there were obviously circumstances that happened up there where if you had somebody that didn‚Äôt have that mental toughness and started to react poorly that really could‚Äôve brought down the whole mission‚Äù Isaacman said.

SpaceX did not respond to CNN Business‚Äô requests for comment.

The toilet anecdote also highlights a fundamental truth about humanity and its extraterrestrial ambitions ‚Äî no matter how polished and glitzy we may imagine our space-faring future biological realities remain.

Excreta in space a history

Isaacman was ‚Äî as numerous astronauts before him ‚Äî bashful when it came to discussing the ‚Äútoilet situation.‚Äù

‚ÄúNobody really wants to get into the gory details‚Äù Isaacman said. But when the Inspiration4 crew talked to some NASA astronauts they said ‚Äúusing the bathroom in space is hard and you‚Äôve got to be very ‚Äî what was the word? ‚Äî very kind to one another.‚Äù

He added that despite the on-board toilet issues nobody suffered any accidents or indignities.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know who was training them but we were able to work through it and get [the toilet] going even with what was initially challenging circumstances so there was nothing ever like you know in the cabin or anything like that‚Äù he said.

Figuring out how to safely relieve oneself in space was however was a fundamental question posed at the dawn of human spaceflight half a century ago and the path to answers was not error-free.

During the 1969 Apollo 10 mission ‚Äî the one that saw Thomas Stafford John Young and Eugene Cernan circumnavigate the moon ‚Äî Stafford reported back to mission control on Day Six of the mission that a piece of waste was floating through the cabin according to once-confidential government documents.

‚ÄúGive me a napkin quick‚Äù Stafford is recorded as saying a few minutes before Cernan spots another one: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs another goddamn turd.‚Äù

The feces collection process at the time a NASA report later revealed was an ‚Äúextremely basic‚Äù plastic bag that was ‚Äútaped to the buttocks.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe fecal bag system was marginally functional and was described as very ‚Äòdistasteful‚Äô by the crew‚Äù an official NASA report from 2007 later revealed. ‚ÄúThe bags provided no odor control in the small capsule and the odor was prominent.‚Äù

In-space toilets have evolved since then thanks to strenuous efforts from NASA scientists as journalist Mary Roach author of ‚ÄúPacking for Mars‚Äù told NPR in 2010.

‚ÄúThe problem here is you‚Äôve got this very elaborate space toilet and you need to test it. Well you‚Äôve got to you know haul it over to Ellington Field board it onto a zero-gravity simulator ‚Äî a plane that does these elaborate up-and-down arcs ‚Äî and then you‚Äôve got to find some poor volunteer from the Waste System Management Office to test it. And I don‚Äôt know about you but I mean to do it on demand in 20 seconds now that is asking a lot of your colon. So it‚Äôs very elaborate and tricky.‚Äù

And Roach writes in ‚ÄúPacking for Mars‚Äù astronaut potty training is no laughing matter.

‚ÄúThe simple act of urination can without gravity become a medical emergency requiring catheterization and embarrassing radio consults with flight surgeons‚Äù she wrote. And because urine behaves differently inside the bladder in space it can be very difficult to tell when one needs to go.

Adapting to space

The human body is evolutionarily designed for life on Earth with its gravity oxygen-rich air and predictable ecological cycles. It is specifically not designed to float disoriented in weightlessness a fact that has caused numerous astronauts to experience a sickening queasiness especially during the first couple of days in orbit.

‚ÄúI vomited 93 minutes into my first flight‚Äù NASA astronaut Steven Smith a veteran of four Space Shuttle missions told one journalist. ‚ÄúThat was the first of 100 times over the four flights. It‚Äôs odd going to a job where you know you‚Äôre going to throw up.‚Äù

NASA has a formal term for the illness ‚Äî Space Adaptation Syndrome which in one paper it estimates about 80% of astronauts have experienced.

Isaacman said that during the Inspiration4 mission he didn‚Äôt feel the urge to vomit. But adjusting to microgravity can be uncomfortable.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just this pooling in your head like when you hang upside down on your bed‚Äù he told CNN Business. ‚ÄúBut you have to kind of find a way to just ignore it and work through it‚Ä¶About a day later it kind of balances out and you don‚Äôt notice it as much.‚Äù

Not all of his crewmates were as lucky. Hayley Arceneaux a 29-year-old cancer survivor who served as Inspiration4‚Äôs medical officer had to administer Phenergan shots ‚Äî an antihistamine used to treat motion sickness to combat nausea Isaacman said.

The inescapable fact is that humans will be battling maladies for as long as we continue to look at space and see it as place we should be going. That‚Äôs why many journalists including Roach have questioned our tendency to romanticize space travel and downplay the harsh realities and risks.

But despite the discomfort Isaacman said he has zero regrets about his decision to spend roughly $200 million on a three-day spaceflight.

‚ÄúI hope that this is a model for future missions‚Äù he said adding that he believes in SpaceX‚Äôs mission to eventually support entire colonies of people living in outer space.

During his flight ‚ÄúI just felt really charged up and energized about the idea that we just have to keep pushing and going further and further.‚Äù
Name_3: Public pressure mounts against Chester incinerator as environmental racism claims pile up
Text_3:
The incinerator has been in Chester since 1992 and residents have criticized its presence since its inception.

In addition to the DEP permitting process opponents see an opportunity to reduce pollution at the plant by pressuring county officials to reject Covanta‚Äôs attempt to renew a contract that ends on April 30.

The county‚Äôs Solid Waste Authority ‚Äî with some members appointed by former Republican-held county governments ‚Äî will decide the fate of the contract renewal.

The next public hearing on solid waste management in the county is planned for 6 p.m. on Sept. 30 when a representative from Covanta will be among the panelists.

‚ÄòNot fair to this community‚Äô

At Wednesday‚Äôs virtual permit hearing before DEP public commenters did not pull punches criticizing Covanta.

Nearly two dozen people registered as speakers for the two hour hearing that was accessible via phone and the internet. Various townships boroughs and municipalities across Delaware County were well represented.

Speakers were given three minutes to state their opinion with the DEP.

Mike Ewall founder and executive director of the Energy Justice Network believes the company is not being properly regulated for harsh pollutants. Smokestacks are monitored daily for four specific pollutants but others are not checked by regulators nearly as often.

‚ÄúThat is not appropriate way to monitor what‚Äôs really coming out of the stack of these facilities and the technology exists to continuously monitor over 50 different pollutants including many different metals particulate matter other acid gases dioxins and furans and more‚Äù said Ewall who has been sparring with Covanta since 1994.

He likened the existing regulation to allowing people to drive all year on the road with no speedometer or rules except on one day.

Ewall wants DEP to require Covanta to continuously monitor its output of particulate matter pollution and other emissions.

WHYY News reached out to Covanta for a response and Nicolle Robles a spokesperson for the company attributed the near unanimous criticism that it received to artificial uproar and scare tactics.

‚ÄúCovanta is a strong advocate of public discourse and believes it is important residents be part of any dialogue concerning their community. It‚Äôs unfortunate that a special interest group has commandeered many of these public hearings with a script that serves only to fear monger‚Äù Robles said.

Erica Berman of Media who works in Chester at the Delaware County Historical Society doesn‚Äôt accept that.

‚ÄúStudying the history of Chester I‚Äôve learned the depth of corruption and systemic racism that allowed for the waterfront to be transformed into a hub of industry pollution and waste.‚Äù She says it was not an accident that the nation‚Äôs biggest incinerator landed in the middle of a low-income Black and brown community.

She believes that allowing the incinerator to continue to operate perpetuates a cycle of racism. She and others on the call cited Chester‚Äôs high rate of asthma among residents as evidence of the lifelong harm being done.
Name_4: Judge ensures recycle pickup
Text_4:
Yvette Stepp of Sequim places cardboard in a recycling bin on Friday at the Port Angeles Regional Transfer Station. (Keith Thorpe/Peninsula Daily News)

PORT ANGELES ‚Äî Curbside recycling and yard waste collection for 9300 city households and businesses will continue past Thursday.

So will operations at the regional and Blue Mountain waste transfer stations ‚Äî used by residents throughout Clallam County ‚Äî while Port Angeles and Waste Connections of Washington Inc. (WCI) officials arbitrate a permanent split Clallam County Superior Court Judge Brent Basden ruled Friday.

Basden granted a temporary restraining order ‚Äî without a fixed end-date ‚Äî sought by the city to prevent WCI from discontinuing waste collection as of Oct. 2 and ordered the binding arbitration sought by Waste Connections so the city and company can devise a termination agreement.

Matt O‚ÄôConnell the Rainier Division vice president of Texas-based Waste Connections Inc. said that almost immediately after the Friday morning ruling company workers began returning about 2000 yard-waste bins that were collected last week in anticipation of the company‚Äôs departure.

‚ÄúThey should be back in time for the following week when yard waste will be in service‚Äù he said.

Public Works Director Thomas Hunter said Friday after the ruling that the arbitration process would begin this week.

‚ÄúWe look forward to having this process‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThe community shouldn‚Äôt have to suffer because someone doesn‚Äôt want to follow the contract and contracted service as it‚Äôs precisely spelled out and as the judge ordered this morning.‚Äù

O‚ÄôConnell said he is looking forward to resolving the dispute.

‚ÄúClearly we are pleased that the judge ordered both of us to move forward toward arbitration‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúOur goal through all of this as we were told in March was to come to a termination agreement as it‚Äôs laid out in the contract. We look forward [this] week to working with the city and working with the arbitrator to accomplish that goal.‚Äù

The city is taking advantage of a 15-year opt-out clause in a 20-year contract it signed with WCI in 2005 and will go back to doing what it did before contracting with the company.

Hunter said he expects the city can provide better service at a lower cost to residents.

‚ÄúOur plan is to take over services as they currently stand‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThe numbers showed the time was now and I think that it‚Äôs likely had the city chosen to continue with the remaining five years we probably would have made the same decision based on how the industry has evolved over time.‚Äù

Waste Connections also built the 18th Street transfer station which it operates and took over operation of the Blue Mountain facility.

WCI employs two drivers four workers at the regional station and one worker at Blue Mountain.

‚ÄúWe are committed to continuing to employ them‚Äù O‚ÄôConnell said. ‚ÄúWe will find a spot for them and we want them to remain part of the Waste Connections and Olympic Disposal family.‚Äù

WCI was paid $6.1 million in 2020 under the contract a total that increases every year subject to the Consumer Price Index and the Fuel Price Index Hunter said.

Thee are 6058 recycling accounts and 3192 yard-waste accounts.

The Port Angeles City Council voted in March to terminate the agreement effective Friday.

Waste Connections sued the city in July claiming $4.8 million in unpaid fees citing breach of contract and a a depressed global recycling market.

The company filed a complaint Sept. 14 to compel the city to engage in binding arbitration which Basden said both sides had agreed on in July.

WCI also wanted the city to pay $3.2 million in termination costs.

Basden ordered the city to pay an $80000 bond to cover costs subject to review by him or the mediator former King County Superior Court Judge Laura Inveen of Hillyer Dispute Resolution in Seattle.

In arguing for the temporary order Chris Cowgill of the city attorney‚Äôs office said the company was insisting the city follow WCI‚Äôs terms and was withholding information such as that dealing with employee and transport operations necessary for the city to determine what constitutes a satisfactory termination agreement.

‚ÄúWhen actual negotiations happened you probably read from the declaration of Mr. Hunter negotiations began with ‚Äòwe will not discuss anything unless the city is willing to attach a $3 million check‚Äô‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThe issue is both ways there has been poor communication‚Äù Cowgill said.

‚ÄúQuite frankly the Oct. 2 date is not doable and I can‚Äôt imagine it would be doable for either party because in refusing to meet and refusing to exchange information WCI hasn‚Äôt received information from the city‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúNegotiations require an exchange of information and not a demand and all the city‚Äôs been receiving from WCI is a demand‚Äù he said adding that the city cannot get enough information from WCI to come up with a counter-proposal.

In arguing against the order Waste Connections lawyer Alexander Wu of Seattle said the city was dragging its feet over preparing for the company‚Äôs departure had not responded for two months to a proposed termination agreement and had avoided setting an arbitration date.

‚ÄúWaste Connections has been preparing for termination since the city supplied notice in March and set this termination date‚Äù Wu said.

‚ÄúThe reason that we‚Äôre here is because the city‚Äôs not ready to take over services‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why they haven‚Äôt agreed to arbitrate before Judge Inveen this week that‚Äôs why they haven‚Äôt agreed to arbitrate with Judge Inveen next week.

‚ÄúAnd that arbitration in its scope is relatively narrow. It‚Äôs an arbitration over what goes in the termination agreement‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúWaste Connections proposed this termination agreement back in April. The city has not made any counter-proposal to that. They haven‚Äôt made any revisions to Waste Connections‚Äô proposal and they haven‚Äôt put forth their own contract.‚Äù

Basden said arbitration was provided for in the contract and that the city did not respond to Waste Connections until the company selected one among four choices.

‚ÄúIt seems relatively clear that the problem here is that the city isn‚Äôt prepared to take over collection of yard waste and recycling‚Äù Basden said.

‚ÄúWhose fault that is is not going to be decided by this court at this point.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I need to make that determination because your agreement provided for arbitration.

‚ÄúIt seems to me at this point since July when everyone agreed to go to arbitration that presumably people have been preparing for that arbitration.‚Äù

________

Senior Staff Writer Paul Gottlieb can be reached at 360-452-2345 ext. 55650 or at pgottlieb@peninsuladailynews.com.
Name_5: Editorial | Urgent need to rethink waste management | Commentary
Text_5:
Jamaica has been struggling with its waste-management system for many decades and there are alarming signs that the garbage problem could develop into a major public-health issue. Mountains of garbage are piling up in cities towns and makeshift dumps and persons say they are being sickened by garbage pollution.

The inability of the National Solid Waste Management Authority (NSWMA) to effectively collect and dispose of tons of waste generated by households and businesses has resulted in residents being confronted by the stench of rotting animal flesh along with infestation of flies rats and other vermin that feed on fetid garbage. The public-health implications are enormous.

Not only is the NSWMA not effective at collecting trash it has not been able to successfully educate citizens on recycling composting and other waste-mitigating action and strategies. Years of talk and clean-up campaigns have yielded negligible results.

The municipal dumps are not properly managed and as we have seen from time to time methane-filled plumes of smoke emanating from these sites are released into the atmosphere to the detriment of the people and the environment.

NSWMA executive director Audley Gordon has all but admitted in media interviews that the agency is unable to cope. Although if one listened to the glowing report card presented by Minister Desmond McKenzie in his contribution to the 2021 Sectoral Debate one may be convinced that the agency is on solid footing.

Headlines Delivered to Your Inbox Sign up for The Gleaner‚Äôs morning and evening newsletters.

After bragging about the mobile app meant to identify those who litter and dump garbage illegally and the training of environment wardens he said: ‚ÄúThe NSWMA continues to demonstrate sound management by earning its own revenues amounting to $440 million over the last fiscal year.‚Äù

He continued: ‚ÄúThe agency continues to be an outstanding example of what can be achieved with major investment from central Government bold and innovative leadership and a dedicated workforce.‚Äù

NOT ENOUGH TRUCKS

But a chastened Mr Gordon confronted by images of garbage heaps all over the country enumerated the problems faced by the agency. First he said there were not enough trucks. They were promised 120 trucks in 2020. They got 20 with no indication of when the others will be delivered.

Added to that the NSWMA is unable to pay in a timely fashion the contractors whose trucks are used to move garbage. In some cases there are reports that contractors have not been paid in months.

Then there is another factor: the recklessness of citizens who wantonly discard their garbage anywhere only for it to contaminate the waterways around us. This is happening despite the creation of the app and hefty fines for littering and illegal dumping.

If the Government is serious about enforcement it could consider setting up special courts to deal with environmental crimes. It could also consider imposing a cess on households with the funds being earmarked for improving collection and disposal of trash.

When will Jamaica a country that depends on visitors for its survival get to the point where it can be ranked as a clean and environmentally friendly destination? That question takes on additional weight because more and more tourists are considering environmental metrics when they make vacation decisions.

The kind of smugness displayed by the minister in reporting on the performance of the NSWMA sadly smacks of short-sightedness. What hope is there for meaningful change if an agency such as the NSWMA is not held accountable for its stewardship?

The problem of garbage is a global concern and developing countries face grave difficulties in resolving the problem. Yet there exists a slew of new technologies that are being used to transform waste disposal into a profitable business with generation of electricity among them. There are in fact companies that have developed a sustainable business model using new technology.

We acknowledge that it is an expensive activity and that there are not enough tax dollars available to make the adjustments to monetise waste. Government has demonstrated that it is incapable of devising the proper systems to fund and manage this activity. It should do the right thing and divest the service.

Name: Waters Corporation
Name_1: Sir Keir Starmer's nightmare is that his party's best supporters hold opinions that horrify people
Text_1:
The Labour Party conference has been in full swing this weekend with every brand of Left-wing visionary crank and dreamer setting out their stall and seeking support.

But one Left-winger has not attended ‚Äì due to fears for her own safety. Even more extraordinary is that she‚Äôs a Labour MP.

Sir Keir Starmer is doing his best to pour oil on troubled waters. But his problem is simple and fundamental: Labour is a coalition of interests that no longer works. The latest flashpoint for the party‚Äôs collapsing coalition is trans rights.

Not long ago it was accepted common-sense that some spaces should be single-sex in the interests of safety or privacy.

But Labour has been racked by bitter arguments over whether or not male-bodied people who identify as women should be treated as women in all circumstances ‚Äì including single-sex spaces.

Sir Keir Starmer is doing his best to pour oil on troubled waters. But his problem is simple and fundamental: Labour is a coalition of interests that no longer works. The latest flashpoint for the party‚Äôs collapsing coalition is trans rights

Activists within the party led by the Labour LGBT+ group say trans women should always be treated as women.

Not only this but the law should be changed so self-identifying your gender is a simple matter of paperwork with no need for medical assessment or any medical changes.

Others such as Rosie Duffield the MP who refuses to attend this weekend‚Äôs party conference take a more moderate approach arguing that there are still some settings where biology matters more than identity.

Early this month Duffield made clear her support for trans people being treated with justice and dignity but said this didn‚Äôt mean a free pass for males to self-identify as women for all purposes.

Self-identifying as a woman she argued should not be ‚Äòa passport for male-bodied biological men to enter protected spaces for biological women‚Äô such as domestic violence refuges women‚Äôs prisons single-sex wards and school toilets.

Opinion polls show this moderate view to be mainstream among the British public.

But for voicing it Labour activists branded Duffield ‚Äòtransphobic‚Äô and ‚Äòan incredibly hateful person‚Äô who one angry activist on Twitter claimed is ‚Äòcampaigning to make trans people‚Äôs lives worse‚Äô.

Others such as Rosie Duffield the MP who refuses to attend this weekend‚Äôs party conference take a more moderate approach arguing that there are still some settings where biology matters more than identity

Following a months-long barrage of threats and abuse Duffield decided to stay away from her own party conference.

And this isn‚Äôt the first time in recent years that Labour‚Äôs radical wing has threatened and abused those they see as their enemies.

First they came for the Tories. In 2015 even then-Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn was forced to condemn the rabble outside the Tory Party conference who harangued and spat at those attending the event.

In 2017 controversy erupted again when effigies of Conservatives were hung from a bridge during their conference in Manchester.

Next the targets were liberal-Left women with political views deemed ‚Äòproblematic‚Äô. They included the BBC‚Äôs political editor Laura Kuenssberg. Though hardly a byword for reactionary conservatism she was given a bodyguard to ensure her physical safety at Labour‚Äôs conference in 2017.

Then the following year at the peak of Corbyn‚Äôs antisemitism crisis Jewish Labour MPs Luciana Berger and Ruth Smeeth brought bodyguards to protect them at the Labour conference.

The Labour Party conference has been in full swing this weekend with every brand of Left-wing visionary crank and dreamer setting out their stall and seeking support (pictured leader Sir Keir and deputy leader Angela Rayner at the conference today in Brighton)

Being on the ‚Äòright side of history‚Äô it seems makes activists feel they are entitled to behave in ways most of us would consider well beyond the pale.

Commendably Starmer has stamped down on the ugly antisemitism that menaced these women.

After being elected leader he suspended the worst offenders from the party and has prompted howls of activist outrage by refusing to return the whip to Corbyn.

But the aggressive brand of self-righteousness that forced Smeeth and Berger to hire bodyguards hasn‚Äôt disappeared.

Instead it‚Äôs hopped from ‚Äòanti-zionism‚Äô to a new pet cause: trans rights. And so far Starmer has been noticeably lacking in backbone when it comes to tackling the new face of Labour‚Äôs revolutionary vanguard.

After figures as diverse as the Archbishop of Canterbury London mayor Sadiq Khan and Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle condemned the harassment of Duffield a Labour spokesman managed only a disingenuous and feeble: ‚ÄòWe believe debate should always be held in an atmosphere of respect for all points of view.‚Äô

Meanwhile the party‚Äôs messages on self-declaration for trans people are still muddled with it insisting it‚Äôs committed both to making it easier to self-identify gender ‚Äì but also insisting it‚Äôs committed to the Equality Act.

Critics point out that Labour can‚Äôt really have it both ways.

The Equality Act allows for single-sex spaces meaning transgender people may be excluded if it‚Äôs a proportional means to a legitimate end. But there‚Äôs little guidance on how this conflict should be managed in practice.

As a result this vagueness means that under activist pressure the single-sex provisions in the Equality Act are often not worth the paper they‚Äôre written on.

Commendably Starmer has stamped down on the ugly antisemitism that menaced these women. After being elected leader he suspended the worst offenders from the party and has prompted howls of activist outrage by refusing to return the whip to Corbyn

Meanwhile a Bristol University feminist group called Women Talk Back was sanctioned by their own student union for excluding transgender women from some events despite invoking their right to do so under the Equality Act. The group is now taking legal action.

If this all seems arcane think of it as just the latest fissure between the two halves of the increasingly fractious pantomime horse that the Labour Party ‚Äì and the Left in general ‚Äì has become.

The back half of that strange beast is the still-large although dwindling part of the electorate that still sees Labour as the party of ordinary people. And the bit in front is a revolutionary vanguard that will stop at nothing ‚Äì not even reality ‚Äì in pursuit of its own vision of utopia. And the different parts want contradictory things.

The back part wants decent jobs affordable housing law and order and a social safety net.

The front part hates the West and the nation state (especially Israel) wants to abolish borders and the police applauds statue-smashing and thinks normal families are an oppressive bourgeois construct.

And they‚Äôre really really passionate about all of it: so passionate they‚Äôll spit at Tories and harass even their own MPs.

So that leaves Starmer not so much spineless as stymied. Because his most enthusiastic activists belong to the front part of the pantomime horse. And he can‚Äôt really do without their energy and commitment.

But that enthusiasm comes part and parcel with their opinions ‚Äì opinions that horrify even ordinary Labour voters let alone the rest of the country.

Ever since Starmer became Labour leader his facial expression has made me think of a man with terrible gas: terrified to move a muscle lest he make a humiliating noise

Ever since Starmer became Labour leader his facial expression has made me think of a man with terrible gas: terrified to move a muscle lest he make a humiliating noise.

His latest attempt to smooth over the roiling digestive issues in his own party was a 12216-word treatise already widely-mocked for containing absolutely no new ideas. But no new ideas is surely the point.

Starmer‚Äôs soothing centrist babble is designed to drown any alarming gurgles (or worse) from below.

He might have saved his breath because it‚Äôs not working. The moderates find it devoid of inspiration while his party‚Äôs radicals have not left off accusing him of being a power-crazed closet Tory.

How much longer can Starmer hold together a coalition that isn‚Äôt even on speaking terms with itself?

No wonder the poor man looks so uncomfortable.

Name_4: Top 10 Share-Buyback Queens ‚Äì Big Tech except Intel Big Banks except Wells Fargo Buffett ‚Äì Incinerate Most Cash ...
Text_4:
Funded by Debt: Since 2012 share buybacks totaled $5.5 trillion corporate debt soared by $4.7 trillion.

They‚Äôre back big time. Three of the big four banks are back ‚Äì while Wells Fargo keeps getting slapped on the wrist ‚Äì after all four were out of it last year due to pandemic-rated financial restrictions. Intel fell out of it. But the rest of Big Tech is in and Apple bigger than ever. Warren Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway after rightfully dissing share buybacks for years has become one of the largest share buyback queens. And Charter Communications has jumped into it massively.

The top 10 companies ‚Äì ranked by their cumulative buybacks over the past five years ‚Äì bought back more of their shares than ever in Q2: $85 billion according to S&P Dow Jones Indices this week accounting for 43% of the total share buybacks by all S&P 500 companies. Since 2014 these 10 companies bought back $1.13 trillion of their own shares.

The two surges in the chart below ‚Äì first after the corporate tax cuts in 2017 and second after Q2 2020 ‚Äì quadrupled the quarterly rate of share buybacks for these 10 companies from around $20 billion a quarter in the four years through 2017 to $85 billion in Q2 (data via YCharts.com):

The top 10 share buyback queens based on their share buybacks in Q2 2021:

Top 10 Companies Share Buybacks in Billion $ Q2 2021 12 months 5-year total 1 Apple [AAPL] 25.6 89.7 334.1 2 Alphabet [GOOG] 12.8 40.0 87.7 3 Facebook [FB] 8.4 19.2 51.1 4 Oracle [ORCL] 8.0 21.6 93.8 5 Microsoft [MSFT] 7.2 27.4 92.4 6 JPMorgan [JPM] 6.2 11.0 81.5 7 Berkshire Hathaway [BRK.A] 6.0 30.5 43.5 8 BofA [BAC] 4.2 8.1 78.5 9 Charter Comm. [CHTR] 3.5 14.9 42.8 10 Union Pacific [UNP] 3.1 5.2 28.1

Rounding out the top 20 are in that order: Lowe‚Äôs Home Depot Morgan Stanley P&G Citigroup Walmart HCA Healthcare Visa Chubb and Mastercard. Wells Fargo and Intel which used to be in the Top 10 have fallen off the list entirely.

In total 294 of the S&P 500 companies reported buybacks in Q2 of at least $5 million down from 335 companies in Q1 2021. But the top 10 did the lion‚Äôs share of buying.

Combined they bought back $199 billion of their own shares in Q2 the fourth largest amount ever behind the records in the three quarters through Q1 2019 following the corporate tax cuts (blue columns in the chart below).

Since the beginning of 2012 the S&P 500 companies have bought back nearly $5.5 trillion of their own shares with the top 10 share buyback queens accounting for 25% of it.

But in recent years this has gotten a lot more top heavy. In Q2 2021 the top 10 accounted for 43%.

But without the Top 10 share buyback queens the share buybacks by the remaining 284 companies amounted to only $114 billion (red line) roughly flat with Q1 and below most quarters in prior years ‚Äì that‚Äôs how top-heavy this scheme has become:

Even today as crazy as this sounds the $5.5 trillion that the S&P 500 companies incinerated on buying back their own shares is a lot of money. They could have been invested in expansion projects in the US and in labor in the US rather than in cheap labor overseas and in training or god forbid the companies could have tried to somewhat less aggressively dodge US income taxes and pay a little more given that the US government deficit has been horrendous for years and has become more horrendous with the corporate tax cut of 2017 and has become a lot more horrendous starting in March 2020

Along with share buybacks comes the corporate debt and it has ballooned as many companies borrowed heavily to fund the share buybacks.

Nonfinancial corporate debt (bonds and loans outstanding owed by companies other than lenders) spiked in the first half of 2020 and in Q2 reached a new record of $11.2 trillion having soared by 73% over the past eight years. The $5.5 trillion incinerated on share buybacks played a large role in creating this debt:

The primary purpose of share buybacks is to undo the dilution of their EPS metric that occurs due to massive executive stock-based compensation packages. These share buybacks hide the cost of stock-based compensation on EPS; and many of those share buybacks are funded with debt but debt doesn‚Äôt impact EPS.

In terms of actually lowering the share count: Only 5.4% of the companies that did share buybacks reduced their share count by at least 4% year-over-year according to S&P. This 5.4% share was down from a 17.8% share a year ago and from the 28.2% share in Q1 2016.

Name_5: How much money do millennials really make?
Text_5:
Your income provides a way for you to pay for housing and food save for retirement and meet other life goals. Some people are fortunate enough to be able to cover all their needs and wants with just one primary income source. Others however have to stretch each paycheck to cover their basic expenses. And according to a report conducted by the TIAA Institute millennials are the generation most likely to face financial strain in areas such as paying down debt and saving money. Millennials ‚Äî classified by the Pew Research Center as people born between 1981 and 1996 ‚Äî have gotten a ton of attention as a generation struggling to balance their lifestyle costs with their financial goals. And a large part of that imbalance could stem from not earning enough money to float their costs. According to data from the U.S. Census Bureau the median millennial household pretax income was $71566 in 2020. However a Sunmark Credit Union study on the spending habits of different generations found that millennials spend an average of $208.77 per day. This includes the average daily costs of groceries housing utilities insurance entertainment eating out and more. That number works out to be $1461.39 spent each week and $5845.56 per month. But at the end of the year the average person will have spent $70146.72 ‚Äî just under the median millennial income. Spending almost as much as they earn each year means that there's less room to save for emergencies or invest for retirement. But with the average cost of rent ‚Äî millennials' largest expense ‚Äî weighing in at $1584 for a studio and $1636 for a one-bedroom in the U.S. many millennials find that their wages just aren't enough to allow them to keep up with the costs of day-to-day life.

Factors affecting millennial earnings

The 2008 recession took a huge financial toll on millennials. A lack of jobs meant that fewer millennials were able to earn income or advance their careers which set them back financially. In fact a report from a non-profit group called the Young Invincibles found that the 2008 economic downturn cost younger workers an estimated $22000 in lost earnings per person. Even after out-of-work millennials finally landed jobs in the years following the recession their salaries had decreased. The Hamilton Project an economic analysis from the Brookings Institute found that prior to economy-related job loss millennials earned around $3640 per month which works out to be $43700 annually. But two years after the recession hit those who landed jobs earned an average monthly income of only $1910 ($23000 per year). Millennials have had to work their way back up from this staggering difference in earnings. And while the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic had an effect that played out across all age groups it seemed as if millennials took yet another hit as they are the largest generation currently in the workforce. According to the Pew Research Center 30% of Americans between the ages of 30 and 49 say that they or someone in their household lost a job due to the pandemic. However it may still be too early to see the pandemic's full impact on millennial earning potential.

How millennials can keep more of their money

If you have your credit card payments under control you can also use your card to earn extra money back when making purchases. You might consider a credit card with a big welcome bonus ‚Äî like the Citi Premier¬Æ Card. Welcome bonuses allow you to earn a large amount of points for opening a card and spending a certain amount of money in a specified time frame. With the Citi Premier Card you can earn 60000 bonus points after spending $4000 in purchases with your card within the first three months of account opening (redeemable for $600 in gift cards when redeemed at thankyou.com). Plus for a limited time earn a total of 10 ThankYou¬Æ Points per $1 spent on hotel car rentals and attractions (excluding air travel) booked on the Citi Travel‚Ñ† portal through June 30 2024. Cardholders can also choose from a large selection of gift cards including department and home stores as well as restaurants. You can use the card to pay for your regular expenses ‚Äî and you should be able to pay it off right away since you'd spend on costs you'd need to pay for anyway ‚Äî and then you'll use your points on things you want to buy.

Lastly you can invest your money and have it grow on its own over time. When you keep all of your cash in a regular savings account your money loses value over time because of inflation which means it'll afford you less and less as the years go by. Investing however gives your money the opportunity to grow even if you don't make any additional contributions (though the more you contribute the more it'll grow). If you're new to investing you might consider robo-advisors like Wealthfront and Betterment which can invest your money into portfolios that best suit your goals.

Bottom line

Millennials have already lost a lot of ground when it comes to their earnings thanks to the 2008 recession and now the Covid-19 pandemic. But by taking some small steps like using credit cards that let them save on interest investing and supplementing their income through side hustles millennials can start to strike a better balance between what they need and what they can afford.
